name: Mount Tai
shortDescription: Most sacred of China's Five Great Mountains, site of imperial feng and shan sacrifices
fullDescription: Mount Tai (Ê≥∞Â±±, T√†ishƒÅn) is the most revered of China's Five Great Mountains and one of the most sacred sites in Chinese religion and culture. Located in Shandong Province, it has been a pilgrimage destination for over 3,000 years and the site where emperors performed feng and shan sacrifices to legitimize their rule through the Mandate of Heaven. In mythology, Mount Tai is associated with the god of the mountain (Taishan Fujun), who judges the souls of the dead, and is believed to be the grandson of Pangu. The mountain represents stability, imperial power, and the connection between heaven and earth.

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Mount Tai symbolizes stability, endurance, and the cosmic pillar connecting heaven and earth. As the eastern mountain, it represents sunrise, birth, and renewal. The feng and shan sacrifices symbolized the emperor's legitimate authority through heaven's mandate. In folk religion, it represents life, death, and the afterlife through Taishan Fujun's judgment.
